tips: Scan old photos at the highest resolution possible before uploading
Clean the original photo or scan carefully to remove dust spots
Use PNG format to avoid additional compression artifacts
Start with 2x upscaling for photos that are already reasonably sized
Consider color correction after upscaling for faded photos

faq.question: Can I restore very old photos from the 1800s or early 1900s?
faq.answer: Yes! Our AI works excellently on vintage photos from any era. The technology is trained on historical photographs and can handle sepia tones, black and white images, and early color photos.

faq.question: Will upscaling change the vintage look of my photo?
faq.answer: Our AI preserves the authentic character and vintage aesthetic of old photos while improving clarity and detail. You won't lose the nostalgic feel that makes old photos special.

faq.question: What's the best way to scan old photos before uploading?
faq.answer: Scan at 300-600 DPI in PNG or TIFF format. Clean the scanner glass and photo surface to minimize dust. For fragile photos, consider photographing them with good lighting instead.

faq.question: Can you fix scratches and damage on old photos?
faq.answer: The upscaling AI can reduce the appearance of minor scratches and improve overall clarity. For heavily damaged photos, you may want to combine our upscaler with dedicated restoration software.

faq.question: How large can I print after upscaling?
faq.answer: With 4x upscaling, a 3x4 inch photo becomes suitable for 12x16 inch prints. 8x upscaling can create wall-sized enlargements from small vintage photos.

faq.question: Is there a limit to how many family photos I can upscale?
faq.answer: Free users get 10 credits to start. Each upscale uses 1 credit. For large family photo restoration projects, our premium plans offer unlimited processing.

Use 4x upscaling for most print applications
For vector-style art, the results are particularly crisp

Maintain color profiles for accurate print reproduction

faq.question: Will upscaling change my art style?
faq.answer: Our AI is specifically designed to preserve artistic styles. It enhances resolution while maintaining your brush strokes, textures, and stylistic choices.

faq.question: What resolution do I need for prints?
faq.answer: For quality prints, aim for 300 DPI at your target print size. A 12x18 inch print needs approximately 3600x5400 pixels.

faq.question: Can I upscale pixel art without it getting blurry?
faq.answer: Yes! Our AI recognizes pixel art and can upscale it while preserving the crisp pixel edges that define the style.

faq.question: How does this compare to Photoshop upscaling?
faq.answer: Our AI uses neural networks trained specifically on artwork, producing significantly better results than traditional interpolation methods used in Photoshop.

faq.question: Can I use upscaled art commercially?
faq.answer: Absolutely. If you own the original artwork, you retain full rights to the upscaled version. We don't claim any rights to your creations.

faq.question: What file format should I use for best results?
faq.answer: PNG provides the best quality as it's lossless. Avoid heavily compressed JPEGs as compression artifacts can be amplified during upscaling.

faq.question: Can I upscale a logo from a website?
faq.answer: Yes! Even if you only have a small logo from a website, our AI can upscale it while maintaining quality. For best results, download the largest version available.

faq.question: Will this work for logos with gradients?
faq.answer: Absolutely. Our AI preserves smooth gradients and color transitions that are often found in modern logos.

faq.question: How does this compare to vectorizing my logo?
faq.answer: Upscaling is faster and works well for raster use cases. For truly unlimited scalability (like signage where you need infinite zoom), consider getting your logo vectorized instead.

faq.question: Will the text in my logo remain sharp?
faq.answer: Yes, our AI specifically enhances text clarity. However, very small text at very high scale factors may have limitations.

faq.question: What size logo do I need for a billboard?
faq.answer: Billboard specs vary, but typically require logos at 300 DPI at the physical size. Our 8x upscaling can help you achieve billboard-ready quality from most website logos.

faq.question: Can I maintain my logo's transparent background?
faq.answer: Yes! Upload your logo as a PNG with transparency, and the output will maintain the transparent background.

faq.question: Will upscaling make me look different?
faq.answer: No! Our AI enhances detail and clarity while preserving your natural appearance, expression, and features. You'll look like you, just clearer.

faq.question: Can I use this for passport or ID photos?
faq.answer: You can upscale ID photos, but always verify that the enhanced photo meets the specific requirements of the issuing authority.

faq.question: Does it work on group photos?
faq.answer: Yes, it enhances all faces in a group photo. For best results on specific faces, consider cropping to that person first.

faq.question: Will it smooth my skin too much?
faq.answer: No. Unlike beauty filters, our AI maintains natural skin texture while improving overall clarity and detail.

faq.question: Can it fix blurry portrait photos?
faq.answer: The AI can significantly improve clarity and reduce blur, but extremely out-of-focus photos may have limited improvement potential.

faq.question: What size portrait do I need for LinkedIn?
faq.answer: LinkedIn recommends 400x400 pixels minimum. Our 4x upscaling can create an excellent LinkedIn photo from most smartphone selfies.

faq.question: What resolution do Amazon product photos need?

faq.question: Can I upscale photos from my supplier?
faq.answer: Yes! Many sellers successfully use our upscaler to enhance supplier-provided photos for their own listings.

faq.question: Will it maintain accurate product colors?

faq.question: Does it work for all product types?

faq.question: Can I process multiple products at once?
faq.answer: Yes! Use our bulk processing feature to upscale entire product catalogs efficiently.

faq.question: Should I upscale before or after background removal?
faq.answer: Upscale first for best results. The AI works better with the full image context, including the background.

howItWorks.description: AI enhances while preserving period characteristics

howItWorks.title: Download Result
howItWorks.description: Get your enhanced vintage photo in high resolution

tips: Scan original photos at the highest resolution your scanner supports
Preserve the original file as well as the enhanced version
Start with 2x upscaling for very old photos, then upscale again if needed
Don't over-process - some grain adds to authenticity
Consider colorization services as a separate step after upscaling

faq.question: Will it remove the vintage look from my photos?
faq.answer: No! Our AI specifically preserves vintage characteristics like sepia tones, period grain patterns, and authentic coloring while improving clarity.

faq.question: Can it work on tintype or daguerreotype photos?
faq.answer: Yes, our AI handles all types of vintage photography including early processes like tintypes, daguerreotypes, and ambrotypes.

faq.question: Is this suitable for museum-quality restoration?
faq.answer: Our upscaler produces high-quality results suitable for museum displays, publications, and archival purposes.

faq.question: How does it handle faded vintage photos?
faq.answer: The AI improves clarity while respecting the faded aesthetic. For color correction, you may want to use additional editing after upscaling.

faq.question: Can it enhance details in very old photos?
faq.answer: Yes, our AI can reveal details that aren't visible in low-resolution scans, though results depend on the original image quality.

faq.question: What resolution should I scan vintage photos at?
faq.answer: Scan at minimum 600 DPI, ideally 1200 DPI or higher for best upscaling results. Higher source resolution means better AI enhancement.
